This sounds like anxiety. The thing about anxiety, that I feel makes it sounds silly but also gives it a lot truth, is that it IS in your head. I‚Äôve suffered from an anxiety disorder my entire life and it‚Äôs not an easy thing to deal with. I have Tourette‚Äôs as well, so believe me, when something is working for my anxiety, I can see the difference! Haha. I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre experiencing this right now though. 

There is help! Cognitive Behavioral Therapy is a great option if you wish to seek treatment. 

If you need something a little more convenient, there are thousands of mindfulness mediation apps, and other mindfulness based resources. Practicing mindfulness has worked WONDERS for my anxiety. Simple going around the room and naming 5 things you can see, 4 things you can hear, 3 things you can feel (touch); is 2 things you can smell, and 1 thing you can taste is a great grounding exercise to help you feel more aware of yourself and your surrounding when you feel anxious. 

Walking, doodling, driving (my personal favorite) whatever helps your thoughts move along an even enough pace so that you can focus your nervous energy for a moment, can be considered meditation. It doesn‚Äôt have to be sitting down. 

The idea isn‚Äôt so much to help in just the small times at the supermarket but as a whole! So during those times you feel more at ease. It‚Äôs something you practice, to live a more mindful life that will have you feeling more at ease, more of the time. It‚Äôs teaching your brain to think, more than it is teaching yourself to deal with specific situations. So it WILL take time, but the mor you practice, the easier it will get. Like riding a bike. 

I hope this helps a little!

Your feelings are valid. Just because other people have feelings or issues doesn‚Äôt mean your feelings or issues are any less valid. What you feel and how you feel is important because it‚Äôs part of YOUR experience. And YOUR experience, is just as valid, and just as important, as anyone else‚Äôs because you were put on this Earth just like everyone else was. 

That being said, I agree that perhaps Cognitive Behavioral Therapy may be beneficial. A Cognitive Behavior Therapist may refer you to a psychiatrist if necessary. 

One thing that I tried that helped me tremendously, was making sure I did one thing, the same thing, everyday, so no matter what, at least I can say THIS thing was accomplished. I made that thing making my bed. And no matter what time of the day, morning evening or night, my bed was always made. And everyday, my bed is made, and for whatever reason, it really helped me along my way. Maybe give that a shot?

Weren‚Äôt even gonna talk to me prior to leaving the hospital if I hadn‚Äôt said something.
